Award.AwardTitle: Arithmetic of automorphic forms: cycles, periods and p-adic L-functions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI will study various problems in the arithmetic theory of automorphic forms suggested by conjectures on algebraic cycles, notably the Tate conjecture and the Bloch-Beilinson conjecture. One of the problems involves proving integral period relations for arithmetic automorphic forms on quaternionic Shimura varieties. These relations are known up to algebraic factors, due to previous work of Michael Harris. The PI proposes to prove much more precise relations that identify more or less exactly the missing algebraic factors. Such relations would have applications to the theory of special values of L-functions. In addition, the methods used to study this problem are expected to yield new constructions of algebraic cycles. Another project involves studying the relations between cycles and p-adic L-functions, especially for unitary groups. This develops and generalizes a theme studied in the PI's previous work with Bertolini and Darmon.

The general area of this proposal is algebraic number theory. More specifically, it deals with the study of algebraic cycles over number fields which may be thought of as a higher dimensional generalization of the solutions in rational numbers or integers to a given polynomial equation. The study of integer solutions to polynomial equations (also called Diophantine equations) is a problem that has interested people for the last two thousand years. It is such a basic problem in mathematics that finding new insights into it is likely to have many applications, not just to other parts of mathematics but also practical in nature. Some of the key objects that will be studied, namely elliptic curves, have many practical applications to coding theory and cryptography. The projects in the proposal will lead to not just a better theoretical understanding of such objects, but also develop new computational tools to study them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work done in this project lies at the interface of three different areas of mathematics, namely algebraic geometry, number theory and representation theory. It is motivated by some of the most mysterious and central problems in mathematics (such as the Hodge and Tate conjectures and the conjecture of Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer) and concerns the theory of "algebraic cycles". Algebraic cycles are  certain geometric sets cut out by polynomial equations. In many cases, one expects the existence of a cycle satisfying certain properties, but it is very hard to show that such a cycle exists. Instead, one can try to understand concrete manifestations of the existence of the cycle which can already be very interesting. Most concretely, the existence of a cycle implies relations between "periods": these are like definite integrals found in elementary calculus, but taken over complicated higher dimensional sets. This project studied such period relations in various contexts suggested by the Langlands program, both because these are of intrinsic interest and because such a study provides valuable hints at where one might look for the hidden cycle. There were two main outcomes: the first is a paper with Ichino on periods of quaternionic Shimura varieties which develops a novel strategy to study relations between periods not just up to rational numbers but even more precisely understanding what prime numbers occur in such period relations. In fact, even a precise conjecture in this direction had not been established previously and one of the outcomes of the project was to state such a conjecture and reformulate it in terms of theta functions, which are very classical functions that have a lot of structure and are amenable to study. It is expected that future work using such theta functions will provide a resolution of this conjecture in many cases. The second main outcome is a paper with Venkatesh on period relations in the case of modular forms attached to arithmetic groups where there is not even a visible underlying algebro-geometric structure. The paper nevertheless formulates a conjecture positing the existence of "higher cycles" explaining such period relations and provides some evidence for this conjecture.
